content.description: Climb a slab up to the prominent white dike arcing across the face. Start with a fun move directly above the first bolt, follow the clip up to a two bolt anchor with rap rings, only need 4 draws.
content.protection:
4 bolts, 2 bolt anchor is now gone:(

Higher up takes 2&3 cams, enjoy the walk off sorry about the person who removed the bolted anchor!
content.location:
Right of

Beginner's One

, the obvious wide crack.

climbs.name: Smear Tactics
climbs.fa: Alan Nelson and Alan Bartlett, Jan. 1984

content.description: This is a low angle face with a short, delicate friction crux.
content.protection: two bolts + gear for the anchor
content.location: near the middle of the west face of The Blob

content.description:
Start up

Safety In Numbers

, but before the first bolt of that route cut right following an arch and finish with a short vertical crack.
content.location:
Shared start with

Safety In Numbers

.

climbs.name: Safety In Numbers
climbs.fa: Mike Waugh, Randy Vogel, Mike Lechlinksi, Craig Fry, Dick Shockley, and Jerry Garcia, Jan. 1978

content.description: This is a runout thin face, o.k. but nothing special.
content.protection: 2 bolts and a few pieces of gear
content.location: This is near the left end of the west face of The Blob.  It is the second face route to the right of the obvious Beginner's Two crack.

content.description: A low crux past an old bolt then easy climbing past several horizontal cracks to the top.
content.protection: One bolt (1/4 inch), gear to 2 inches
content.location:
Starts up and left from

Beginner's Two

.

content.description:
Climb up and right following a thin white dyke but when the larger dyke of

Swagger

is reached c

ontinue straight up the smooth face to the top.
content.location:
Starts just right of

Beginner's One

and left of

Swagger

.

climbs.name: Hobbit Roof
climbs.fa: Steve Godshall, June 1971, FFA: John Long, 1972?

content.description:
Approach: Hobbit Roof is on the west face (backside) of the aptly-named Blob formation.  Look for the obvious roof 20' off the deck.

This is a short route, but really fun!  I'd give it 3 stars if it were longer.  Thin and crimpy face climbing past one bolt (10d crux) lead up to the intimidating roof.  The 10b roof protects very nicely with a #.75 Camalot.  Get a good jam, take a deep breath, and fire it!  Smooth sailing from here up the beautiful hand crack (#2 Camalot).  Belay in crack.

Descent: scramble off climber's left.
content.protection: 1 bolt (3/8"), #.75,1,2 Camalots (1 ea.)  Extra #1-#3 for anchor.

content.description: Climbs a generic grainy slab with zero protection.
content.location:
Located between

Smear Tactics

and

Berkeley Dyke

.

climbs.name: Dialing For Ducats
climbs.fa: Alan Nelson and Alf Randell, December 1987

content.description: This is a two bolt face route just right of the upper portion of Beginner's Two.

climbs.name: Berkeley Dyke
climbs.fa: Alan Nelson and Alan Bartlett, Jan. 1984

content.description: This is a nice thin face climb, but don't try it unless you are ready for long runouts.
content.protection: one bolt + gear for the anchor
content.location: This is the first face climb to the left of the obvious Beginners One crack.  Follow a right-slanting dike to a bolt, then go up.

content.description: A beauty to look at, it had to be done. Who care's the grade if the climbing is fun?

climbs.name: Beginner's Twenty-six
climbs.fa: Dave Davis, Don O'Kelley 12/71, FFA: John Long, Rick Accomazzo, and John Mokri, 1/73

content.description: The name of this climb was presumably inspired by the nearby, easy Beginner's One and Beginner's Two routes.  This short climb has a very  short crux sequence by a bolt, consisting of about three moves.    They are not your normal JT thin face moves.
content.protection: one bolt and perhaps a few pieces of gear
content.location: near the right end of the southwest face of The Blob

content.description: This route is only somewhat similar to Beginner's Two, but perhaps easier due to the lack of a steep 'pod' as had by it's neighbor.  On the West Face of The Blob, there is an obvious crack on the upper half. Scramble up to this crack via a low-angle slab; mind the scaling rock, it can crumble.  Access the crack, place some pro and climb to the top. The route is 5.3 or so, yes, but not sewn up and there is a little scaling on the bottom half- not the best intro to leading.
content.protection: Carry a light standard rack.Maybe S?  The climbing is mostly hikable, but that doesn't mean that it is well protected. Maybe not the best first lead for a neophyte climber.

content.description:
Starts near

Beginner's One

and climbs up and left across the face to merge with

Berkeley Dyke

near the top of that route.
content.protection: No gear available, toprope or solo like the first ascent
content.location:
Located 20 feet right of

Berkeley Dyke

.
